Listings will be printed if space permits. Submission deadline is two weeks before the event date. Please send submissions to bridges@thestarphoenix.com.

# ART

Rouge Gallery

Until May 14 at 245 Third Ave. S. Liver N’ Onions by Landon Peters. A montage celebrating a few of the more eclectic diners of Saskatoon’s past.

The Gallery at Art Placement

Until May 19 at 228 Third Ave. S. Rewind by Louise Cook.

Gordon Snelgrove Gallery

Until May 20 in Room 191 of the U of S Murray Building. SCYAP Urban Canvas XI: Cats, Ninjas, Mermaids, Serial Killers and Poutine. Closing ceremonies May 20, 10 a.m. to 12 p.m. Mayor Don Atchison and several dignitaries will be in attendance.

SCYAP Gallery

Until May 20 at 253 Third Ave. S. Infinite Places by Kathy Allen.

Collector’s Choice Art Gallery

Until May 21 at 625D First Ave. N. Artwork by Mary Masters and Joan Weber. Gallery artists are also on display.

330g

Until May 21 at 330 Ave. G S. Mother and Child by Mindy Yan Miller.

Gallery on Third, Watrous

Until May 23 at 102 Third Ave. E., Watrous. Repetition, an OSAC Arts on the Move show. Featuring 18 artists from three Saskatchewan printmaking collectives.

The Gallery at Frances Morrison Central Library

Until May 26 at 311 23rd St. E. Nesting by Dee Gibson.

Studio Nest by Dee Gibson is on display at The Gallery at Frances Morrison Central Library

Biggar Museum & Gallery

Until May 28 at 105 Third Ave. W., Biggar. In partnership with OSAC and the Biggar & District Arts. Annual Adjudicated Art Show. The adjudication, by Carol Wylie, takes place May 28, 1:30 p.m.

Affinity Gallery (Saskatchewan Craft Council)

Until May 28 at 813 Broadway Ave. Royal Ceremonial Tapestry: Marapu Weavings from Sumba Island. An exhibition of textiles from the private collection of Geoffrey Bendel. Reception May 6, 7 p.m. to 9 p.m. Q & A with the collector May 9, 10 a.m. to 1:30 p.m.

Handmade House Showcase

Until May 28 at 710 Broadway Ave. I Go Through Phases, contemporary glass by Louisa Ferguson.

Hues Art Supply

Until May 31 at 1818 Lorne Ave. Artwork by Lana Cowell, Celeste Delahey and Paul Trottier.

Gallery on the Bridges

Until May 31 on the third, fourth, sixth and seventh floors of the Atrium at Saskatoon City Hospital. Recent works by Bill Oleniuk, paintings of rural Saskatchewan by William Philpott and Four Seasons paintings by Connie Schuler.

Conveying the Message of Change

Tuesdays to Fridays until May 31, 9 a.m. to 3 p.m., at St. Paul’s United Church. Sponsored by the Saskatchewan Council for International Co-operation. A collection of art posted from more than four decades with messages of peace, respect, justice, environmental rights and democracy. Admission is free.

Calories Bakery & Restaurant

Through May at 721 Broadway Ave. Mélange by Gale Hagblom. Proceeds from the sale of the painting “Sunrise” will go to Adelle House and the Elizabeth Fry Society.

Eye Gallery

Until June 3 at 117-1132 College Dr. Eye on U by Trint Thomas. Black and white, hand-developed photos of street fashion in Vancouver, Paris and Amsterdam, using a vintage camera.

Hand Wave Gallery

Until June 9 in the gallery and until Aug. 4 in the garden at 409 Third Ave., Meacham. Steel Works by M. Craig Campbell, Daryl Richardsin, James Korpan, Les Potter and Rob Sexauer. Large sculptures in the Grass Garden Maze and smaller sculptures in the gallery.

Humboldt and District Museum and Gallery

Until June 15 at 601 Main St., Humboldt. Heavy Metal, an OSAC group exhibition by B.A. Conley, Ken Delgamo and Mark Vitaris.

AKA Artist-Run

Until June 18 at 424 20th St. W. Peripheral Influence. Works by Joi T. Arcand, Heather Benning, Bogomir Doringer & Bernd Oppl, Maria Grün, Agnes Hamvas, Michael Koch, Zachari Logan, Clint Neufeld, Astrid Sodomka, Laura St. Pierre and Franz Wassermann.

Station Arts Centre, Rosthern

Until June 18 at 701 Railway Ave., Rosthern. Local Colour and Woman in Between, two exhibits by Wade Kotelo.

Market Mall Children’s Playland Art Gallery

Until June 20 at 2325 Preston Ave., in Market Mall. Expressions, artwork by students from St. Philip School.

St. Thomas More Gallery

Until June 24 at 1437 College Dr. Saskatchewan Printmakers Association exhibit. Works by Michelle Brownridge, Patrick Bulas, Karli Jessup, Caitlin Mullan, Jannik Plaetner, Robert Truszkowski, Monique Martin and Michael Peterson.

North Star Gallery

Until Sept. 30, 16 kilometres west of Humboldt and six kilometres south. Paintings by Karen Holden and pottery by Mel Bolen.

# FAMILY

CJ’s Climb and Play

Daily, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m., in Bay 4 of 619 South Railway St. W. in Warman. Saskatchewan’s newest indoor playground. For children up to age 12. Visit cjsclimbandplay.com or their Facebook page.

Fun Factory Indoor Playground

Daily at 1633C Quebec Ave. A giant indoor playground for young children. Adults and children under one year are free. There is a separate fenced in area for children under two.

Children’s Play Centre

Daily at Lawson Heights Mall. A fun, safe, environment for preschool children to play. Children must wear socks in the play area. Please note this is an unsupervised play area, and adults must stay with and supervise children at all times.

Market Mall Children’s Play Centre

Daily just off the food court at Market Mall. This play area is free and has different level slides. Children must wear socks in the play area.

Mommy & Me Canvas

May 13, 7 p.m., at Wet Paint Pottery, 3110 Eighth St. E. Suitable for ages six to 12. A one-evening class for moms and kids. The project is Mushroom Buddies. Register at 306-373-3219.

Kid Yoga Classes

Ages five to 10 on Saturdays, 11:30 a.m. to 12:15 p.m.; home-schoolers ages five to 12 on Mondays, 10:15 a.m. to 11 a.m., at Yoga Life, 2-115 Third Ave. S. Classes taught by Nina Zettl. Classes are six weeks. Register at freedomfromwithinyoga@gmail.com.

Prenatal Partner Workshops: Yoga for Childbirth

Saturdays, 1 p.m. to 4 p.m., at Birth Rhythms, 248 Third Ave. S. Instructed by Nina Zettl. No previous yoga experience is required. Classes are six weeks. Register at freedomfromwithinyoga@gmail.com, 306-361-8852.

Mom and Baby Yoga

Mondays, 11:15 a.m. to 12:30 p.m., at Yoga Life, 2-115 Third Ave. S. Classes taught by Nina Zettl. For mothers with babies as young as six weeks. Classes are six weeks. Register at freedomfromwithinyoga@gmail.com.

Postnatal Yoga

Mondays, 12 p.m. to 1 p.m., at Pregnancy and Parenting Health Centre, 248 Third Ave. S. Beginner to intermediate yoga designed to help with postpartum recovery. Register at msjpriestley.wix.com/pureenergy. No class on stat holidays.

Canadian Light Source (CLS) Public Tours

Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, 2 p.m., at the Canadian Light Source, 44 Innovation Blvd. The synchrotron research facility is open for the public. Preregistration is required. Call 306-657-3644, email outreach@lightsource.ca or visit lightsource.ca/education/public_tours.php.

Prenatal Yoga

Mondays, 6 p.m. to 7 p.m., at Pregnancy and Parenting Health Centre, 248 Third Ave. S. Taught by a doula and certified yoga teacher. Call 306-251-0443 or email msjpriestley@gmail.com. No class on stat holidays.

Stay and Play

Tuesdays and Wednesdays, 9:15 a.m. to 11:15 a.m., September through April. For children up to age five. Semi-structured, crafts, snacks, story time, toys, activities. Email stayandplaysaskatoon@gmail.com or visit the Facebook page.

Pre-School Drop-In Gymnastics Classes

Tuesdays and Wednesdays, 9:30 a.m. to 11:30 a.m., at Marian Gymnastics Club, 343 Edson St. A parent-supervised drop-in program. Drop-in requires the purchase of a punch card. No registration required. Information at 306-934-0944.

Preschool Story Time

Tuesdays, 10:30 a.m. to 11 a.m., at McNally Robinson, 3130 Eighth St. E. For children ages three to five in the Circle of Trees. Call 306-955-1477.

Tiny Tots Sensory Classes

Tuesdays, 11 a.m. to 11:50 a.m. Hosted by My Smart Hands Saskatoon. Explore sensory play through various items while supporting this learning through various signs. Information at mysmarthandssaskatoon.com.

Mom & Baby Outdoor Stroller Fitness Classes

Tuesdays until May 26, 11:30 a.m. to 12:25 p.m.; Wednesdays May 4-27, 10 a.m. to 10:55 a.m.; Wednesdays June 1-24, 9:30 a.m. to 10:25 a.m., at rotating locations along the Meewasin Trail. A six-week baby-friendly exercise class. Meet new Moms and receive a whole body workout. Information and registration on Facebook or saskatoonstrongmoms@gmail.com.

Level I Baby Sign Language Classes

Tuesdays, 2:15 p.m. Hosted by My Smart Hands Saskatoon. Caregivers and children will build their American Sign Language vocabulary. Information at mysmarthandssaskatoon.com.

Shop ‘n Stroll

Wednesdays, 9:30 a.m. to 10:30 a.m., meet in front of Customer Service at Lawson Heights Mall. Power-walking, body-sculpting moves and socializing for parents and babies. Preregister at runnersandbootiesfitness.com. No classes on stat holidays.

Stars and Strollers

Wednesdays, 1 p.m., at Centre Cinemas in The Centre. Choice of two movies each week. A baby-friendly environments with lowered volume, dimmed lighting, a changing table and stroller parking in select theatres.

Pop In & Play!

May 19, 9:30 a.m. to 11:30 a.m., at Erindale Alliance Church, 310 Perehudoff Cres. A monthly theme, learning centres, snacks and occasional speakers. Information at office@erindalealliance.ca.

Parent and Toddler Yoga

Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 10:15 a.m., and/or Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 11:15 a.m., at Yoga Life, 2-115 Third Ave. S. Classes taught by Nina Zettl. For parents and their toddlers ages one to five. Classes are six weeks. Register at freedomfromwithinyoga@gmail.com, 306-381-8852.

Breastfeeding Cafe

Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 11:30 a.m., at Westwinds Primary Health Centre, 3311 Fairlight Dr. A drop-in support group for breastfeeding women.

Prenatal Breastfeeding Classes

Monthly classes, 6 p.m. to 8 p.m. at City Centre Family Physicians, 200-3211 Preston Ave. S. Taught by Registered Nurses/Lactation Consultants Cindy Leclerc and Jana Stockham. Register at cindyandjana.com/classes.

Playgroup

Monthly and seasonal events. Hosted by Prairie Hearts Learning Community, a group of families inspired by Waldorf philosophy. Programming is aimed at children ages two to five, but all ages welcome. Information on their Facebook page.

Engineering for Kids

Children ages four to 14 can learn about technology and how engineers help it develop. Get information and register at engineeringforkids.net/saskatoon or 306-978-4186.

BRICKS 4 KIDZ® Saskatoon

Regular after-school programs, preschool classes and camps for kids of all ages at various locations in Saskatoon. An atmosphere for students to build unique creations, play games, and have fun using LEGO® bricks. Visit bricks4kidz.com or call 306-979-2749.

Saskatoon Public Library Programs

Ongoing daily programs for children and families. Find the calendar at saskatoonlibrary.ca.

# SPECIAL EVENTS

Annual Sherbrooke Book Sale

May 13, 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., at Sherbrooke Community Centre, 401 Acadia Dr. Hosted by Sherbrooke Community Day Program. Funds support the program and their Me to We program.

Borden Farmers’ Market

Fridays until Oct. 7, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m., at Borden Fire Hall in Borden. Lunch is available 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. Information at 306-997-2159 or Facebook.

Third Annual Seniors’ Globe Walk Celebration

May 13 at the Western Development Museum. Presented by the Saskatoon Council on Aging. A celebration lunch. Information at scoa.ca/globewalk, 306-652-0027 or globewalk@scoa.ca.

Saskatoon Gem & Mineral Show

May 13-15 at Prairieland Park. Organized by Circum-Arctic Gallery. Gem and mineral enthusiasts from all over Canada bring an array of unique gems, minerals, rare fossils, handmade jewelry, fancy beads and lapidary. With lapidary technique demonstrations, geode cracking, gold panning, a silent auction and door prizes. Tickets at saskatoon-gem-show.eventbrite.com or at the door.

Barbershop Harmony Time

May 13 at Knox United Church, 838 Spadina Cres. E. Saskatoon Chimo Barbershop Chorus’s spring show. Featuring The Executives, Sharp Flats and 42nd Street Singers. Tickets at 306-652-5622, McNally Robinson or at the door.

National Youth Band of Canada

May 13, 7:30 p.m., at Holy Cross High School, 2115 McEown Ave. In concert with the Saskatoon Brass Band. Tickets and information at 306-659-7600, or tickets at the door.

Story Circle for Adults

Third Friday of the month, September to June, moved to second Friday in May due to long weekend next week, 7:30 p.m., at the Unitarian Centre, 213 Second St. E. Bring a story or come to listen. Potluck snacks are welcome. Admission is by donation. May 13 theme is what doesn’t kill us makes us stronger.

Yuk Yuk’s Comedy Club

May 13, 9 p.m., at Park Town Hotel, 924 Spadina Cres. E. Featuring Brett Martin and Lisa Baker. Tickets at parktownhotel.com, 306-244-5564 or at the door.

Flea Market & Bake Sale

May 14, 8 a.m. to 1 p.m., at Mayfair United Church. Pancake breakfast, 8 a.m. to 10 a.m. Barbecue lunch, 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. Admission at the door. Everyone is welcome.

Church Garage Sale

May 14, 8 a.m. to 2 p.m., at McClure United Church, 4025 Taylor St. E. Household items, small appliances, small furniture, electronics, baking, books, jewelry, purses and scarves. Pancake breakfast 7:30 a.m. to 10:30 a.m., hotdog lunch 11:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m.

Church Garage Sale and Bake Sale

May 14, 8 a.m. to 3 p.m., at Faith Lutheran Church, 2801 Preston Ave. S. Wide variety of items and baking inside and outside. With barbecue hamburgers and beverages. Information at 306-373-5605.

Country Gospel Breakfast Buffet and Concert

May 14, 9 a.m., at Smiley’s Buffet, 702 Circle Dr. E. Hosted by the Country Gospel Music Association. Featuring Back 40 and Per Vinding. Admission at the door. Information at 306-242-7431, 306-229-8600.

Annual Nutana Sweep into Spring

May 14, 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. at the dump site in the 800 block of Ninth St. E. A neighbourhood back alley cleanup. Bring debris to the drop-off spot during this time. To volunteer contact sweep@nutana.ca.

Westside Community Centre’s Clothing Depot

Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., at 3488 Fairlight Dr. Free clothing for all ages, free baked goods from a local bakery. They take donations of clothing, footwear, accessories and toys. Information at 306-222-8737.

Saskatoon Shimmy Mob

May 14 at the Saskatoon Farmers’ Market. A global fundraising flash mob event that celebrates World Belly Dance Day. With a bazaar, a hotdog barbecue, entertainment from 1 p.m. to 2 p.m., and a bouncy house for kids. Admission is free. Funds raised will support the Saskatoon Crisis Nursery.

Saskatoon Shimmy Mob celebrates World Belly Dance Dayon May 14.

Blossoming Into Spring

May 14, 2 p.m. to 4 p.m., at Grace-Westminster United Church, 505 10th St. E. UCW spring tea. Admission by donation.

Stars on Ice

May 14, 7:30 p.m., at SaskTel Centre. Featuring Elvis Stojko, Tessa Virtue & Scott Moir, Patrick Chan, Meagan Duhamel & Eric Radford, Joannie Rochette and Javier Fernandez. Tickets at 306-938-7800, ticketmaster.ca.

Appalachian Spring

May 14, 7:30 p.m., at TCU Place. Presented by the Saskatoon Symphony Orchestra. Featuring pop artist Sarah Slean. Works by Copland, Berlioz, Purcell and Hatzis. Tickets at 306-975-7799, tcutickets.ca.

Here, There and Everywhere

May 14, 7:30 p.m., at Broadway Theatre. Saskatoon Fiddle Orchestra’s 12th annual spring show. An evening of spirited traditional tunes. Tickets at McNally Robinson, 306-652-6556, broadwaytheatre.ca.

Fundraising Gala

May 14, 8 p.m., at Studio 914, 914 20th St. W. Presented by La Troupe du Jour. A New Orleans-themed evening. Live entertainment by Don Griffith and The Second Line. With a silent auction, Creole and Cajun food, draws and prizes. Tickets at latroupedujour.ca.

Walk for Lupus

May 15, 12:30 p.m. registration, 1 p.m. walk, starting at the River Landing Amphitheatre, 110 Spadina Cres. E. Hosted by the Lupus SK Society Inc. Walk and raise funds for lupus awareness, support services and research. Information and pledge sheets at idriedger@sasktel.net, 306-227-9562.

Saskatoon Lions Band Practices

Sundays, 1 p.m. to 3 p.m., at 238 Ave. V N. The community marching band meets to rehearse. Young musicians ages 12 to 21, with at least one year of playing experience, are welcome. Colourguard flag twirling practice is at the same time, with no experience necessary. Information at 306-249-5013, brenda.armstrong@sasktel.net.

Tonight It’s Poetry

May 15, 7:30 p.m., at The Woods Alehouse, 148 Second Ave. N. Community Stage featuring Lip Balm. Admission at the door.

French and English Skills Development

Mondays, 12:05 p.m. to 12:55 p.m., at Le Rendez-vous francophone, 308 Fourth Ave. N. Hosted by Inspiration Bilingue Toastmasters Club. Develop and practice French and English communication and leadership skills. Information at inspirationbilingue.toastmastersclubs.org.

Country Farms Marketplace

Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., at Confederation Mall. An indoor marketplace across from Urban Planet. Home cooked lunch, desserts, preserves, handcrafted items and home-based business vendors.

Saskatoon Brass Band Rehearsals

Saskatoon Brass Band rehearses Tuesdays, 7:30 p.m. to 9:30 p.m.; Saskatoon Youth Brass rehearses Thursdays, 6:30 p.m. to 7:30 p.m.; and Bridge City Brass rehearses Thursdays, 7:30 p.m. to 9:30 p.m. Information at 306-934-1470.

Saskatoon Farmers’ Market

Open year round. Wednesday and Sunday, 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., and Saturday 8 a.m. to 2 p.m., farmers are in attendance. Tuesday to Friday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., and Saturday and Sunday during market hours, food service and specialty shops are open. Information at saskatoonfarmersmarket.com. Contact 306-384-6262, skfarm@sasktel.net.

Bargain Basement Store

Wednesdays and Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. at St. Paul’s United Church, 454 Egbert Ave. Clothing, jewelry, purses, belts and more. With a free soup lunch Wednesdays at 12 p.m. To donate clothes call 306-955-3766, visit spuconline.com or email rachsam1@gmail.com.

Mayfair Carpet Bowling

Wednesdays, 1:15 p.m., at Mayfair United Church. Beginners and experienced players are welcome. For information call 306-651-2151.

Family Alzheimer’s Caregiver Workshop

May 18, 2 p.m. and 6:30 p.m., at Cliff Wright Library, 1635 McKercher Dr. Hosted by Home Instead Senior Care. Understanding ways to manage the challenges of living with Alzheimer’s and other types of dementia. Admission is free. Register at 306-931-4663.

Literature Matters Discussion

May 18, 7:30 p.m., at Grace-Westminster United Church, 505 10th St. E. Adapting Shakespeare: a discussion with Shakespeare on the Saskatchewan. Featuring directors Will Brooks, Anita Smith and Joshua Beaudry. With moderator Joanne Rochester. Information at 306-966-5486, english@usask.ca, artsandscience.usask.ca/english.

Adult Drop-In Gymnastics Classes

Wednesdays, 8:30 p.m. to 10:30 p.m., at Marian Gymnastics Club, 343 Edson St. A drop-in program for ages 16 and up. Drop-in requires the purchase of a punch card. No registration required. Information at 306-934-0944.

Presentation & Workshop

May 21, 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., at St. Paul’s Co-Cathedral, 720 Spadina Cres. E. Physician-Assisted Suicide: How to present the case for palliative care without raising your voice by Peter Nation. With MP Brad Trost. Fee includes lunch. RSVP by May 18 to info@catholicvoice.ca.

Prairie Sky Farmers’ Market

Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., at St. Paul’s United Church, 424 Egbert Ave. Vendors sell local food and craft items.

Carpet Bowl

Thursdays, 12:15 p.m., at Nutana Legion Hall, 3021 Louise Ave. Hosted by the Nutana Senior Citizens Association. Lunch and coffee are available for a fee.

Adult Pottery Painting

May 19, 6 p.m., at Wet Paint Pottery, 3110 Eighth St. E. Suitable for ages 13 and up. A new one-evening class each month. The project is Do More of What You Love. Register at 306-373-3219.

SIFC Dances

Thursdays, 7 p.m., in room 13 at Albert Community Centre, 610 Clarence Ave. S. Saskatoon International Folkdance Club. Learn dances from many countries around the world. First night is free. Information at 306-374-0005, sifc.awardspace.com.

Book Signing at McNally

Regular book signings at McNally Robinson, 3130 Eighth St. E. For schedule and information visit mcnallyrobinson.com/saskatoon_events.

English for Employment Class

Hosted by the Saskatoon Open Door Society. Improve English pronunciation and communication, and learn what you need to find work in Saskatoon. Information or registration at 306-250-4337, 306-653-4464, 306-250-4338, jhaugen@sods.sk.ca, ajunek@sods.sk.ca.

# THEATRE

Dadventure

May 14-23 at The Refinery. The world premiere of this play by Andrew Taylor. Jeremiah dreams his father is captured by Paper Pirates and a team of Dream Travellers arrive to help him find his father. A story for all ages. Tickets at wideopen.ca, 306-683-9460 or at the door.

The Romeo Project

Until May 15 at Persephone Theatre’s BackStage Stage. Presented by the Persephone Young Company. A deconstructed re-imagining of Romeo and Juliet for the 21st century. A daring, provocative exploration of young love, sexuality and violence which takes place in, on and around the desks of a high-school classroom. Tickets at persephonetheatre.org.

Popcorn Elder

Until May 15 at Dancing Sky Theatre in Meacham, and May 19-29 at Studio 914, 914 20th St. W. Written by Curtis Peeteetuce. Presented by the Gordon Tootoosis Níkaníwín Theatre Company and Dancing Sky Theatre. Inspired by the Arizona sweat lodge incident of 2009, this play focuses on the practice of plastic shaman and elders on the Indigenous community. Tickets at 306-384-7727, persephonetheatre.org. For ages 12 and up.

Salt Baby

Until May 15 and May 19-22 at The Refinery. Presented by Live Five. A young woman born and raised on Six Nations reserve struggles to find a place of her own in an urban area. A comedic journey of self-discovery and finding the difference between racism, ignorance and indifference. May 12 is a pay-what-you-can preview. Tickets at 306-653-5191, ontheboards.ca.

Popcorn Elder

 

Mary Poppins

Until May 22 at Persephone Theatre. An enchanting musical based on the stories of P.L. Travers and the Walt Disney film. Tickets at 306-384-7727, persephonetheatre.org.

]]> 0513_bqc_bridges_events_shimmy_mob-W.jpg jbennettstarphoenix UNDATED - VANCOUVER, BC - Submitted August 2, 2011 - Swedish metal band Amon Amarth plays the Commodore Ballroom in Vancouver Aug 4. Note: Johan Hegg is centre. (With Francois Marchand story.) [PNG Merlin Archive] Selena Gomez performs at WE Day California at the Forum on Thursday, April 7, 2016, in Inglewood, Calif. Studio Nest by Dee Gibson is on display at The Gallery at Frances Morrison Central Library May 11, 2013 - 11:58 a.m. - Shimmy mob performed at the Saskatoon Farmer's Market to raise funds for Adelle house as they celebrated World Belly Dance day. Bridges photo by Michelle Berg Two wines in a box worth considering http://thestarphoenix.com/life/bridges/two-wines-in-a-box-worth-considering http://thestarphoenix.com/life/bridges/two-wines-in-a-box-worth-considering#respond Fri, 13 May 2016 07:00:11 +0000 http://thestarphoenix.com/?p=134356 ]]> Full disclosure: I don’t usually drink white wine from a box. For the most part, boxed white is best drunk with a shot of gin, a squeeze of lime, and maybe some muddled cilantro or mint. You may like it cut with soda water and lime, and skip the gin et al. (I also recommend a couple of drops of Absinthe. Grapefruit bitters work, too.)

The only boxes I can recommend — and may, on rare occasion drink — are those holding Sauvignon Blanc. At the moment Sauvignon Blanc is too valuable to go into a box, generally speaking. I’ve been hoping to find a German or Canadian Riesling in a box as it currently is undervalued, but no luck so far. The strange blends in most “dry white” boxes smell musty, taste sweet and have about the same acidity you can find in a glass of water.

So the only two whites I recommend are Copper Moon Sauvignon Blanc and Jackson-Triggs Sauvignon Blanc. They are quite similar wines. Copper Moon is paler. The bouquet of the J-T is a bit mustier — that clears off quickly — and I think Jackson-Triggs is a bit sweeter.

For whatever reason I usually default to the Copper Moon. If you were to tell me you preferred the Jackson-Triggs, I wouldn’t argue.

If you are one of those people who takes off for the weekend in the summer and doesn’t want to complicate packing, consider boxed wines this year. Were it my cottage, I’d stick a box of one of these in the fridge for myself and whoever dropped in.

Copper Moon Sauvignon Blanc $40 ***

Jackson-Trigg Sauvignon Blanc $40 ***

Next week I think I have to review something in a bottle or I’ll burst into tears. Other stuff on Twitter @drbooze.

The collision took place Thursday around 7 p.m. at 20th Street and Avenue P South. A vehicle travelling south on Avenue P did not stop for a red light at 20th Street, colliding with two other vehicles heading east on 20th Street, police said in a news release.

A 62-year-old man from Saskatoon who was driving one of the eastbound vehicles was taken by ambulance to hospital with non-life-threatening injuries.

There will be no charges laid, police said.

]]> http://thestarphoenix.com/news/local-news/saskatoon-man-dead-after-medical-condition-causes-three-vehicle-collision/feed/ 0 saskatoon police ambulance car thestarphoenix Duck family gets police escort to safety http://thestarphoenix.com/news/local-news/ducks-family-gets-police-escort-to-safety http://thestarphoenix.com/news/local-news/ducks-family-gets-police-escort-to-safety#respond Fri, 13 May 2016 02:26:18 +0000 http://thestarphoenix.com/?p=137795 ]]> Saskatoon police helped a feathered family reach safety on Thursday afternoon. 

Members of the bike patrol unit escorted a mother duck and her ducklings through Saskatoon’s busy downtown, blocking traffic for a short time at the intersection of Fifth Avenue North and 22nd Street East and as they crossed Spadina Crescent toward the riverbank.

Const. Joey Taylor was one of the officers who guided the ducks to water with fellow officer Const. Ryan Geib.

“We came because the citizens were concerned,” Taylor said. “They saw them downtown, didn’t want anybody to get hurt and didn’t want any of the ducks to get hurt.”

Members of the Saskatoon Police Service bike unit help a family of ducks navigate their way through downtown on Thursday afternoon. The officers were able to guide the feathered family to the South Saskatchewan River after blocking traffic for a short time at the intersection of Fifth Avenue Nother and 22nd Street East and as they crossed Spadina Crescent toward the riverbank.

Taylor said police blocked traffic and kept curious onlookers at a distance to ensure they were able to reach the bank of the South Saskatchewan River through Kiwanis Memorial Park.

“It’s certainly not a surprise that we got called, but at the same time, I’ve never escorted ducks down to the riverbank,” he said, adding it’s just another aspect of the job besides catching criminals.

“There’s certainly a lot of community policing to our job and there’s a lot more to it than what people read about in books and magazines,” he said.

“Obviously every day is different, and sometimes we have to deal with the safety of animals, including the safety of the public.”

The officers ensured the ducks made it safely into the river, helping one duckling into the water after it fell behind.

]]> http://thestarphoenix.com/news/local-news/two-vehicle-crash-at-avenue-p-and-20th-street-leads-to-traffic-restrictions/feed/ 0 051216-CRASH0003.JPG-avenue_p_and_20th_crash-W.jpg thestarphoenix Man thanks STARS for a second chance at life http://thestarphoenix.com/news/local-news/man-thanks-stars-for-a-second-chance-at-life http://thestarphoenix.com/news/local-news/man-thanks-stars-for-a-second-chance-at-life#respond Fri, 13 May 2016 01:37:32 +0000 http://thestarphoenix.com/?p=137713 ]]> “I’ve taken that beautiful trip in that red helicopter. I wouldn’t recommend it for most anybody.”

With those words, Jason Simpson, who says his life was saved by a STARS air ambulance crew, shared his story at the launch of the annual STARS fundraising lottery on Thursday.

Simpson said he was south of his farm, 90 miles southwest of the Saskatoon, when a truck hauling a 30-foot cattle trailer collided with his truck.

The impact sent him — and the seat he was buckled into — through the centre console and partially through the passenger window as his truck rolled three times before coming to a stop in the ditch, he said.

After local EMS removed him from the wreckage, a STARS crew arrived at the scene.

STARS, a non-profit organization that offers air ambulance service to people in remote areas, operates from six bases across Western Canada, including locations in Saskatoon and Regina.

“STARS came out to give their assessment and pick up whatever was left of the pieces of me,” Simpson said.

“I don’t remember much of that or the next two or three weeks.”

The crash left Simpson with damage to his vertebrae and severe internal injuries. As a result, his heart stopped twice. His helicopter ride to the hospital took 21 minutes, and without it, he never would have survived, he said.

He spent nine months in hospital recovering from the crash, including 11 weeks of rehabilitation, and now uses a wheelchair. Despite the challenges he faces today, Simpson said he is grateful for the second chance at life.

“The positive to the whole thing is I’m still here,” he said. “I’ve got kids that are loving me, thinking of me, and never look back at any of the complications.”

This year’s STARS lottery boasts prizes worth more than $4 million.

]]> http://thestarphoenix.com/sports/golf/delaet-seven-shots-back-of-strong-day-at-players-championship/feed/ 0 031116-Valspar_Championship_Golf-0312_Graham_Delaet-W.jpg thestarphoenix Caswell Hill stabbing nets man 15-year sentence http://thestarphoenix.com/news/crime/caswell-hill-stabbing-nets-man-15-year-sentence http://thestarphoenix.com/news/crime/caswell-hill-stabbing-nets-man-15-year-sentence#respond Thu, 12 May 2016 23:57:51 +0000 http://thestarphoenix.com/?p=137752 ]]> Albert Gardipy’s family has one question for the man who killed him: Why?

On Thursday, after Craig Allen Mintuck stood up to plead guilty to stabbing Gardipy and was sentenced to 15 years in prison, they were left without a clear answer.

Mintuck was high on drugs, probably crystal meth, when he met Gardipy on Oct. 8, 2014, in the kitchen of the home in the Caswell Hill neighbourhood where Mintuck was renting a room. Gardipy was there with some family members, visiting a man who was renting another room in the home, Crown prosecutor Bryce Pashovitz outlined in Saskatoon Court of Queen’s Bench.

Craig Allen Mintuck

Gardipy, 32, had been drinking that day with his sister and a cousin. During what seemed like a friendly visit in the kitchen, drinking some coolers, Mintuck suddenly stabbed Gardipy once in the abdomen in a motion that Gardipy’s sister didn’t even realize was violent, until she saw the blood on Gardipy’s white T-shirt.

The eight-inch knife blade sliced into Gardipy’s aorta; he died of blood loss.

“The burning question, one that will probably never be answered, is why?” Gardipy’s mother Sandra Neapetung said in court, addressing Mintuck.

“What could my son have said to you to warrant such a senseless, brutal attack? … Why stab a stranger, an acquaintance, when there was no altercation? Life is so precious, and it can be gone in a split second and survivors of violence are forever changed.”

Mintuck’s lawyer, George Combe, said he didn’t have an answer for the family.

“All I can indicate to you is that my client, Mr. Mintuck, due to a state of drunkenness, has actually no memory or any consistent memory of what transpired,” Combe said in court. “I know it’s important to families to try and get some kind of closure, but I cannot provide the answer to you because there is no answer.”

Mintuck was too nervous to address the family directly, Combe said, but wrote a letter that Combe read on his behalf.

“The remorse that I feel knowing that I took someone special away from you is one of the most devastating feelings I have ever come to know,” Mintuck wrote. 

The 36-year-old’s criminal record is so long and full of violent convictions his lawyer described it as “atrocious.” After his arrest in connection with Gardipy’s death, however, Mintuck disclosed for the first time his own history as a victim of abuse when he was a child and began getting counselling while on remand, Combe said.

Mintuck turned to alcohol and drugs as a result of his experiences, and when he’s intoxicated, he becomes a different person, Combe told court.

“It is not an excuse for his behaviour. It’s just putting his life in context.”

Mintuck was charged with second-degree murder in Gardipy’s death, but following a preliminary hearing and discussions between lawyers, the Crown agreed to accept a plea to manslaughter. The Crown and defence jointly recommended a sentence of 15 years, with no eligibility for parole until Mintuck has served half of his sentence (offenders are generally eligible for parole after serving one-third of their sentence).

Justice Gerald Allbright accepted the joint submission, noting it was “very much” at the high end of the range for manslaughter sentences in Saskatchewan.

hspray@postmedia.com

]]> http://thestarphoenix.com/news/crime/caswell-hill-stabbing-nets-man-15-year-sentence/feed/ 0 051216-GARDIPY,_Albert.jpg-227570358-GARDIPY-_Albert-W.jpg hspraysp Craig Allen Mintuck Idylwyld Dr. overpass rehab starts Sunday http://thestarphoenix.com/news/local-news/idylwyld-dr-overpass-rehab-starts-sunday http://thestarphoenix.com/news/local-news/idylwyld-dr-overpass-rehab-starts-sunday#respond Thu, 12 May 2016 23:52:54 +0000 http://thestarphoenix.com/?p=138027 ]]> Major work on the Idylwyld Drive overpass at Ruth Street is set to start Sunday and while two-way traffic will be allowed, there will be restrictions in the area.

The rehabilitation work is scheduled to last until the end of August with crews working one side at a time so traffic isn’t completely restricted during the summer, according to a city news release. Speed and lane restrictions will be in place throughout the summer.

Here are the city’s instructions for zipper merging:

“To zipper merge correctly, as you see the ‘lane closed ahead’ sign and traffic backing up, stay in your current lane up to the point of merge. Then take turns with other drivers to safely and smoothly ease into the remaining lane. Vehicles in the merging lane must signal, and drivers in the through lane must let one vehicle merge. This makes the traffic flow more quickly and efficiently for drivers in both lanes.”

The work will include stripping the surface asphalt, replacing the concrete deck and other miscellaneous repairs, according to the city. More information can be found online at saskatoon.ca/bridges and saskatoon.ca/zippermerge.

]]> http://thestarphoenix.com/news/local-news/idylwyld-dr-overpass-rehab-starts-sunday/feed/ 0 022716-construction_signs.jpg-225633120-construction_signs-W.jpg thestarphoenix Multiple vehicles struck on Forrester Road http://thestarphoenix.com/news/local-news/multiple-vehicles-struck-on-forrester-road http://thestarphoenix.com/news/local-news/multiple-vehicles-struck-on-forrester-road#respond Thu, 12 May 2016 23:28:09 +0000 http://thestarphoenix.com/?p=137894 ]]> An elderly woman driving a maroon Pontiac Grand Prix allegedly struck a series of vehicles on Forrester Road Thursday afternoon.

Brian Grover, a Canada Post letter carrier, said he was driving southbound when the northbound car veered into his lane near the corner of Forrester Road and Peeling Avenue, hitting him head-on.

“The vehicle kept coming at me. I couldn’t see her, so I thought maybe the vehicle was empty and just rolling,” he said.

“She hit me and then veered off and kept driving.”

The woman continued to drive down the street, and after another car swerved out of her way, she hit several parked cars, according to Grover.

“They think she may have had a small stroke,” Saskatoon fire department Capt. Brian Smith said.

City police reported that seven vehicles were damaged, Smith said.

“She just lives on Pendygrasse (Road), so she hasn’t come far from where she lives.” 

The woman, who looked disoriented, was taken by ambulance to Royal University Hospital.
